Well, there only ever has been uh one
age of empire, and it began with the
dawn of civilization. All of history is
the history of empires. There really
isn't much else. There's prehistory and
we can try and work out what nonliterate
hunter gatherers thought. But it's a
tough assignment. But history is the
study of what we sometimes call
civilization. It's the study of life in
settlements uh very often life in
cities. And it doesn't go f much back uh
much further back than uh 4,000 years
ago. Now, for most of the 4,000-year
period that historians concern
themselves with when they are writing
about civilization, the main political
actors are empires. And they dominate
the life of the historian because
empires are so much better at generating
evidence uh at generating enduring
documents, generating enduring uh
architecture than other policies. They
they just last longer and they build
more and they write more. Uh so the
notion that there is such a thing as a
discrete age of empire that isn't
co-terminus with the history of
civilization is of course absurd. There
is no point in the history of
civilization uh when there wasn't at
least one empire and usually there were
more uh competing or coexisting
ignorance of one another's existence. In
our time there was a a wonderful uh
illusion which was generated by thinkers
on the left not only Marxists but also
radical liberals uh that a thing called
imperialism had come into existence
quite recently as recently as the 19th
century and that in the 20th century uh
it died or was going to die. This was
the central hypothesis of J. Hopson, of
Lenin, and of generations of of writers
on the left. But imperialism is
something different. I mean, imperialism
is a term of abuse that you you throw at
empires. Empires are always with us. And
even when imperialism was proclaimed to
be dead after World War II, uh both the
reigning empires that emerged
victorious, the Soviet Union and the
United States carried on behaving like
empires. They accused one another of
being imperialists. Uh but they
themselves both operated very much as
empires. So I don't think the age of
empires is likely to end unless of
course you think civilization is going
to end. And that I wouldn't rule out.
